College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content:
Dr. Ramesh Akkina is a professor of Microbiology, Immunology, and Pathology at Colorado State University, Fort Collins, USA. 

A PhD from the University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, he did his post-doctoral work and was a visiting professor at the UCLA School of Medicine, Los Angeles. 

He is a leading researcher in the HIV field and made many ground breaking discoveries in viral infectious diseases. His early contributions were in Influenza virology and stem-cell based gene therapy strategies. His lab pioneered in work with humanized mice with a transplanted human immune system for HIV and Dengue virus research as well as for delivery of novel gene therapy molecules. 

Recent work developed new pre-exposure prophylaxis methods to prevent HIV transmission, successfully tested anti-HIV si-RNAs and aptamers and showed that immune exhaustion during HIV infection can be partly reversed by PD-1 blockade. 

Ongoing work is centered on HIV latency, prevention, novel therapeutics and viral evolution. His research is supported by multiple NIH grants. He is a member of many editorial and international grant review boards. He is currently the Center Director for Global Virus Network at Colorado State University and Chair of the NIH AIDS ADDT grant review study section.
fields.Spatial Angle: Aids around the world?

fields.Primary Story Content: There are currently more than 40 million victims of slavery around the world, with most of them being women and girls. This illegal industry generates approximately $150 billion every year. Dr. Lumina Albert, associate professor of management in the College of Business at CSU, applies her background in management and marketing to the fight against human trafficking in the U.S. and abroad. As a board member for Rescue:Freedom International and consultant for other organizations, Albert provides key input on issues ranging from strategic public relations to organizing social marketing campaigns.

Extreme weather event communication, Communication in the development and distribution of science and technology, Public engagement with science

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Primary Story Content: In today’s data-driven world, global challenges cannot be solved without access to relevant, accurate information — fast. Under the direction of professor and founder Mazdak Arabi, CSU’s One Water Solutions Institute (OWSI) has developed a robust portfolio of cloud-based software and research tools to equip public, private, and nongovernmental entities with world-class research and innovations necessary to address existing and emerging challenges in watershed sustainability and management. OWSI’s eRAMS (Environmental Resource Assessment and Management System) platform, created by Arabi, delivers location-based information, data analytics and modeling, and content management tools to inform the plans, policies, and practices of water-focused stakeholders and decisionmakers around the world.
fields.Spatial Angle: map of projects worldwide
fields.es-StoryTitle: Modelado de la calidad del agua

fields.Primary Story Content: Most people are familiar with the plight of polar bears affected by climate change, or rhinos affected by poaching, but few are likely familiar with the huemul — the rarest species of deer in the Americas, described as a mix of a kangaroo and a mountain goat in a deer body. Without the same name recognition, animals like the huemul or the saiga (a kind of antelope) or the takin (a member of the camel family) are less likely to receive the funding needed to study the challenges they face and the efforts that could mean the difference between rebound and extinction. Wildlife conservation biologist and CSU researcher Joel Berger advocates for these lesser-known species and one of the world’s preeminent field biologists, and focuses on species in North America, Mongolia, Namibia, and the Arctic.
fields.Spatial Angle: Included a map (.docx) but no spatial files. Recreate the map (so it's interactive).

fields.Primary Story Content: Dr. Albert Bimper, Jr., senior associate athletic director for diversity and inclusion and associate professor of ethnic studies at CSU, understands that student-athletes in college often don't see much further than the boundaries of their playing field. Balancing the demands of school and competition keeps many athletes from experiencing some of the best parts of college life — including the chance to study abroad. Bimper, a 2006 CSU graduate who went on to play on the Indianapolis Colts Super Bowl champion team, returned to his alma mater with a goal of promoting diversity and inclusion in Athletics and improving the overall academic experience of student working their way through college as athletes. Bimper created the Green and Global service experience, which takes a group of student-athletes each summer to Petersfield, Jamaica, to stretch their boundaries, immerse themselves in another culture, and learn to better understand their role and connections as global citizens.
fields.Spatial Angle: Jamaica Country Boundary and Larimer County Boundary with line connecting the two

fields.Primary Story Content: Chemistry brought us plastics, and now CSU professor Eugene Chen is using chemistry to save us from these synthetic materials and their unintended environmental impacts. Roughly 56 million tons of plastic trash are overflowing the world's landfills and bobbing in our oceans. By 2050, this means there will be more plastic (by weight) in the oceans than fish. Chen and his research team are creating fully recyclable polymers that can compete with conventional petroleum plastics.
fields.Spatial Angle: Global map of plastic waste per country... how do we make this interactive?

fields.Research Focus: Interactions between climate and terrestrial ecosystem carbon cycles from local to global scales

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Research Focus: The Dean lab, of the Center for Vector-Borne Infectious Diseases (CVID), has a major focus on the development of a probiotic vaccine platform utilizing the probiotic organism Lactobacillus acidophilus. Specific applications include vaccines against human rotavirus, feline coronavirus (FECV) and SARS-CoV-2. We study the host mucosal immune response and immune mechanisms of multiple adjuvant strategies. The relationship between the host microbiome and mucosal immunity and the impact of oral vaccination on the intestinal microbiome are also active areas of research. Study of the immunpathogenesis of viral infections is an overarching emphasis.

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content: Many species of wildlife have been adversely impacted, or even have gone extinct, due to climate change. Polar bears, however, have become the poster species, as the effects of climate change are the most pronounced in the Arctic due to rapidly melting sea ice. Colleen Duncan, a veterinary pathologist at CSU, studies infectious disease and population dynamics in wildlife, and works with wildlife researchers at the U.S. Geological Survey and the U.S. Department of Agriculture to collect biological samples and health data from polar bears in northernmost Alaska.
fields.Spatial Angle: Alaska study area; this could be an interactive map about health... let's push on how to make this a bit more dynamic and less locational.

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content: After a mosquito takes a bloodmeal from its host, it can be thought of as a small, flying syringe. If we can trap these insects and study the contents of their bloodmeals, we can understand not only which mammal the mosquito took a bloodmeal from but also which infectious diseases they may be carrying. Working in Guatemala, CSU professor Greg Ebel's lab is exploiting these feeding patterns to better characterize which viruses, bacteria, and parasites are circulating in humans and animals.
fields.Spatial Angle: Population density heat map of mosquitos around the world; what is the interactive component here? Can we look at a feeding pattern of a single mosquito? Or a few examples?

fields.Research Focus: Wildlife habitat connectivity and illegal trade in Ethiopia
fields.Primary Story Content:
Fields of Expertise
Data, GIS, and Modeling, Ecology, Ecosystem Dynamics, Education and Outreach

Areas of Interest
Ecosystem services, Invasive species, Mountain ecology

Biography
Dr. Paul Evangelista is a Research Ecologist at the Natural Resource Ecology Laboratory (NREL) and Assistant Professor in the Department of Ecosystem Science and Sustainability. His research at the NREL has extended across a broad array of interests, including invasive species, forestry, rare and endangered wildlife, ecosystem services, fire ecology, and climate change. His interests are frequently examined in the context of space and time through a suite of integrative spatial modeling techniques that combine field data, traditional and expert knowledge, geographic information systems (GIS), remote sensing and spatial statistics. Such analytical approaches have been used for early detection of invasive species, discovery of new wildlife populations, mapping land-cover and critical habitats, and predicting species’ distribution in response to changing climates. Dr. Evangelista’s research spans a wide breadth of ecosystems, including semi-arid canyon lands of the American Southwest, coniferous forests of the Rocky Mountains, Afro-alpine communities of Ethiopia’s highlands, and marine systems of the Atlantic Ocean. His research is regularly coupled with non-traditional educational programs that aim to build capacity through experiential learning, applied science and stakeholder engagement. This is best demonstrated by his advisory role with the DEVELOP Program, part of NASA’s Applied Science Program, hosted by the NREL and the US Geological Survey. Ultimately, Dr. Evangelista’s broad research interests center on supporting sustainable management, stewardship and conservation of natural resources.
fields.Spatial Angle: Bale Mountains, Ethiopia
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of a lush green valley

fields.Primary Story Content: While outdoor air chemistry is a much-studied discipline, the science of indoor air chemistry has been less explored — until recently. Most U.S. residents spend 90% of their time indoors, and the combination of chemicals and products used for everyday household activities like cooking and cleaning can lead to unexpected and potentially harmful airborne chemical compounds. CSU atmospheric chemist Delphine Farmer and her CU collaborator Marina Vance won a Sloan Foundation grant to map the airborne chemistry of a typical home — a first-of-its-kind project dubbed HOMEChem — which will serve as a baseline study of what a person at home, doing typical home activities, can expect to breathe.
fields.Spatial Angle: Hmmm

fields.Research Focus: Climate change and pastorial livelihoods - Mongolia
fields.Primary Story Content: Rangelands make up three-quarters of Mongolia and are vitally important to the Mongolian people, and important to wildlife populations globally. Since 2008, CSU professor Maria Fernández-Giménez has led the Mongolian Rangelands and Resilience Project, tracking the impacts of ecological and climate change on Mongolia’s traditional herding families and strengthening connections between natural resource science and the country’s policymakers. Fernández-Giménez was awarded the Order of the Polar Star in 2016 — the highest civilian honor Mongolia bestows on foreign nationals.
fields.Spatial Angle: Let's brainstorm this map. It would be cool to do something that plays with policy and rangeland use...

fields.Research Focus: LiDAR/Archaeology - Mexico, Central and South America
fields.Primary Story Content: In Honduras, a previously hidden ancient city came to light when archaeologist and CSU professor Chris Fisher used LiDAR technology to look under the dense tree canopy and undergrowth of the jungle. Fisher’s groundbreaking, or really ground-viewing, use of LiDAR has changed the face of modern archaeology, speeding discovery by radically shortening the time it takes to “uncover” previously undiscovered sites. Ultimately, Fisher’s research expeditions in the jungles of Honduras and Mexico aim to help us better understand the causes and consequences of urbanism and environmental change.
fields.Spatial Angle: Amanda: I am open to where we take this. Ideas include locations where this LiDAR technology has been used to uncover ancient cities or finding existing map assets that could be dynamic and engaging. Slide 3.

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content: Malaria, a preventable and potentially fatal disease transmitted by mosquitos, kills 445,000 people, mostly children, each year. In Burkina Faso, nearly every single person has malaria parasites in his or her system during the rainy season, and children can get the disease repeatedly before they develop immunity. Dr. Brian Foy, a professor in the Department of Microbiology, Immunology and Pathology at CSU, found that the use of Ivermectin, typically used to treat parasitic worms, led to a significant reduction in cases of malaria among children under the age of five. While Ivermectin has been known to kill blood feeding insects like mosquitos, Dr. Foy thinks it may also have an effect on the malaria parasite inside the body. If he's right, the findings could have implications for communities and inviduals across West Africa.

fields.Research Focus: Harnessing Next-Generation Sequencing Technologies for Eco-Evolutionary Studies of Herbicide Resistance and Weed Biology
fields.Spatial Angle: Herbicide use in the country
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of golden wheat crops

fields.Primary Story Content: For pastoral people in East Africa, daily life revolves around the herd of animals that sustain them — and the land they travel to make sure the animals have room to graze and grow. As the climate changes, their traditional lifestyles are also changing, from subsistence to greater reliance on local villages for food, health care, and other services. CSU Anthropologist Kathleen Galvin has spent 30 years learning from the people who populate East African savannas. Listening to the Maasai share knowledge of climate change and the challenges it creates in their daily lives, Galvin also brings them together in a conversation with scientists and civil leaders to better understand the real human impacts of climate change on this vulnerable population.
fields.Spatial Angle: Kenya on a map of Africa

fields.Research Focus: USAID project in water resources with Pakistan; also USAID projects in Vietnam and Iran

College/Division: Office of the Vice President for Research (OVPR)
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of blood collection tubes

fields.Primary Story Content: Individuals on the autism spectrum have different ways of thinking. Some are photorealistic visual thinkers, others are pattern thinkers who view things spatially, and still others think verbally. And CSU Professor Dr. Temple Grandin says the world needs all these different kinds of minds engaged in solving problems.

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Primary Story Content: The world runs on water — and Neil Grigg, a civil and environmental engineering professor at CSU, studies how to protect water systems from natural disasters and terrorist attacks. This focus is just the latest aspect of Grigg's critical research; he's been helping to educate and work alongside the world's top water administrators since the 1960s. His research on engineering and management systems for water resources has influenced policy and infrastructure in Colombia, Egypt, Brazil, Somalia, and worldwide.
fields.Spatial Angle: Major waterways in Brazil

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Research Focus: Enviro Justice, Uranium Mining - Navajo Nation
fields.Primary Story Content: In 1979, toxic and radioactive material from the Church Rock uranium mill in Northwest New Mexico spilled into the Puerco River and made its way onto the Navajo Nation, whose people were not alerted of the spill’s toxic dangers until days later. It was not until 2008, however, that Congress authorized a five-year cleanup plan for the affected area. Dr. Gilbert John, a CSU microbiologist and member of the Navajo Nation, works to study and better understand the health issues and psychological impacts of the uranium disaster on the Navajo people, who used the river's water for drinking, irrigation, and livestock. John also actively empowers young Native students to pursue careers in STEM disciplines.
fields.Spatial Angle:
Navajo Nation; layering toxic and radioactive material zones with known spills + tribal nations around the U.S.?

Perhaps work from a map like this: https://www.epa.gov/navajo-nation-uranium-cleanup

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Research Focus: Bat viruses & infectious disease ecology in Uganda
fields.Primary Story Content: Bats, the only mammals with powered flight, are the second-most abundant order of mammals behind rodents and carry an equally impressive assemblage of viruses, many of which can make people sick. In Uganda, Dr. Rebekah Kading's lab studies not only which viruses the bats are infected with, but also how those viruses may be transmitted. By better understanding how these pathogens spread, we can paint a picture of the possible ways humans may be exposed, and how to prevent the next virus outbreak.
fields.Spatial Angle: map of Zika forest; how do we make this interactive by looking at pathogen spread?

fields.Primary Story Content: What we call things matters, and when it comes to streams and small waterways, it can matter a lot. Under the EPA’s recent Navigable Waters Protection Rule, streams classified as “ephemeral streams” — those which only flow briefly after rain or snowmelt — are not protected under the Clean Water Act. With fewer protections, more pollutants can be washed downstream — but some streams classified as ephemeral may actually be intermittent or seasonal, which would qualify them for protection. That’s where CSU professor Dr. Stephanie Kampf comes in. Dr. Kampf has been working for four years to map and define small headwater streams. Kampf and her team recently enlisted the help of the public through the Stream Tracker Project, an app that allows users to collect and submit their own data on nearby waterways.
fields.Spatial Angle: Ask researcher for maps of watersheds that they have created (maps mentioned in blurb)

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Research Focus: Atmospheric chemistry; aerosol chemistry and physics; thermodynamics and cloud physics; air pollution
fields.Spatial Angle: Atmospheric chemistry - cloud physics - air pollution
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of the sun setting over the ocean and an aerosol filter

fields.Primary Story Content: The Geospatial Centroid in the Morgan Library at CSU, directed by professor Melinda Laituri, serves a dual role. CSU faculty and students can use a multitude of GIS programs through the Centroid to map and analyze data across disciplines and for a variety of purposes — vegetation cover, population growth, animal migration. But Dr. Laituri also wants the Centroid to be an educational tool, promoting critical thinking around how to use tools like GIS properly, and both what can and cannot be learned from technology.
fields.Spatial Angle: Let's work with Laituri on this and perhaps showcase one of the Secondary Cities Interactive maps that she has developed.

fields.Research Focus: Plant Pathogens - China and the Philippines
fields.Primary Story Content: Dr. Jan Leach, associate dean for research and professor of Bioagricultural Sciences and Pest Management in the College of Agricultural Sciences at CSU, combats world hunger one grain of rice at a time. Defending one of the world's most important food crops from the ravages of pests and climate change, driven by a strong sense of purpose in her work, Leach partners closely with rice growers and scientific collaborators in the Philippines and worldwide. She believes collaboration is key to protecting the food that sustains most of the developing world.

College/Division: College of Health and Human Sciences
fields.Research Focus: Working with the China Institute of Sport Science in Beijing centered around novel approaches to understanding the barriers to physical activity and facilitating a physically active lifestyle to enhance the overall health of the public.
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of kids playing tug of war

fields.Primary Story Content: Supply chain management is usually used to build up a business, but CSU professor John McDonald wants to use supply chain management to bring down wildlife-destroying criminals. McDonald’s work in Africa is centered in Sri Lanka. Illegal wildlife trafficking generates an estimated $23 billion each year in the worldwide criminal economy. Thriving illegal businesses, just like legal ones, have a steady — and often complicated — integrated flow of purchasing and distribution operations. Disrupting the supply chain can kill the business. Understanding the supply chain of wildlife trafficking may be able to help slow the crime and prosecute criminals.

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of a researcher conducting COVID19 Coronavirus MIP Vaccine research

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Research Focus: Dr. Mahmoud’s research program has three major thrusts. The first thrust pertains to spatial and temporal quantification of community resilience subjected to extreme natural hazards including wildfires, tornados, hurricanes, flooding, and earthquakes. The second thrust is focused on assessment and development of resilient and sustainable infrastructure systems subjected to natural and man-made hazards including single and multi-hazards such as blast, fire, earthquakes, and wind or the combination of such. The third major thrust pertains to assessment, evaluation, and repair of deteriorated infrastructure subjected to high and low-cycle fatigue. He has conducted various studies on fatigue evaluation and he has performed numerous in-service assessment of major structures across the U.S. that resulted in the development of proto-type retrofits that have successfully been implemented and adopted by various design specifications.
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Close up view of a steel bridge

fields.Primary Story Content: The world’s population is expected to exceed 9 billion by 2050. With this growth will come heightened demand for clean water, healthy food, manufactured goods, and abundant energy — all requiring accelerated natural resource development and extraction. Stephanie Malin, environmental sociology professor and founding member of the Center for Environmental Justice at CSU, researches the impacts and outcomes of energy production and globalization on the health and sustainability of Earth’s finite ecosystems, resources, and communities. In her book, The Price of Nuclear Power: Uranium Communities and Environmental Justice, Malin asks whether nuclear power provides a socially sustainable solution in the age of climate change mitigation, exploring the intersection of legacy uranium mining and current efforts to renew uranium production at sites such as the Piñon Ridge Uranium Mill in western Colorado.
fields.Spatial Angle: Map of Oil and Gas infastrucutre in Colorado that brings together population growth and water somehow.
fields.es-StoryTitle: El precio de la energía nuclear

fields.Primary Story Content: Approximately 16% of the world’s population (1.2 billion people) lives without electricity, imposing a major barrier to participating in today’s economy. Dale Manning and the Smart Village Microgrid Laboratory seek to test and install energy microgrids in rural Rwandan communities to provide local and sustainable sources of electricity for years to come. To achieve village-level electrification, the CSU Energy Institute is working with the University of Rwanda to build mirrored microgrid labs at both locations to facilitate continued collaboration between the two institutions.
fields.Spatial Angle: World at night map with Rwandan boundary overlayed...or how can we play with light in the map? How can we look at access to power around the world, and in Rwanda specifically, by "lighting up the map"?

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content: Sometimes referred to coloquially as "zombie deer disease," chronic wasting disease (CWD) is a prion disease affecting deer, elk, reindeer, and moose. While the exact mechanisms aren't fully understood, prions -- misfolded proteins -- cause neurons to degenerate by forming plaques in the central nervous system. As neurons die, holes are formed in the brain and other neural tissue, leading to dramatic weight loss, listlessness, trouble walking, and eventually death. While there has never been a reported case of CWD in humans, a jump to humans is not outside of the realm of possibility. And humans already experience other protein-misfolding diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and diabetes. CSU's Candace Mathiason is a leading researcher in the area of prions -- while working on her Ph.D., she demonstrated for the first time that prions are carried in bodily fluids and can be transmitted without direct bodily contact -- and hopes that her research into mechanisms of transmission can shed light on not just CWD, but a wide range of neurodegenerative diseases.
fields.Spatial Angle:
Distribution of Chronic Wasting Disease in North America, updated April 01, 2022.

https://www.usgs.gov/media/images/distribution-chronic-wasting-disease-north-america-0
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of a deer herd in a grove of birch trees

College/Division: College of Health and Human Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content: In developing countries like Ecuador, as populations shift from rural to urban areas, diets often shift from traditional, grain- and vegetable-based fare to a more Western diet, high in sugar and fat. Professor Chris Melby with the Colorado School of Public Health at CSU studies how nutrition — and lack of access to diverse, healthy, nutritious foods — contributes to the chances of having a life-changing illness like stroke, heart disease, or diabetes. Melby is working with colleagues and graduate students in Ecuador to study how to help communities navigate this "nutrition transition," maximizing dietary diversity and minimizing risks for malnutrition and obesity.
fields.Spatial Angle: human migration; increase in health outcomes; rural diets and urban diets
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Close up image of a bunch carrots

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Research Focus: Steven Miller received his BSc in Electrical and Computer Engineering from U.C. San Diego (1995), and MS (1997) and PhD (2000) in Atmospheric Science from Colorado State University. His areas of interest include satellite-based remote sensing of the Earth/atmosphere system from a wide assortment of sensor technologies including active/passive systems spanning the optical to microwave portions of the electromagnetic spectrum. From 2000 to 2007, he worked at the Naval Research Laboratory in Monterey, CA in the Satellite Meteorological Applications Section, where he developed numerous value-added satellite imagery tools for operational users (including mineral dust, snow cover, cloud optical properties, low cloud/fog, fire, thin cirrus, deep convection, natural color, contrail, volcanic ash, and nighttime low-light applications). His mineral dust detection algorithms for MODIS and SeaWiFS were among the first to exploit blue-band absorption properties. In 2005, Dr. Miller published the first satellite detection of a widespread bioluminescence phenomenon (the ‘Milky Sea’) using the DSMP Operational Linescan System.  This was followed in 2021 by new detections by the next-generation Day/Night Band low-light sensor. Dr. Miller joined CIRA in 2007 as a Research Scientist and Deputy Director. In 2021 he joined the Faculty of CSU’s Department of Atmospheric Science, where he serves as Professor and Director of CIRA.  He continues work in developing satellite techniques geared toward operational end-users.
fields.Spatial Angle: Atmospheric Science/ Milky Seas - Indian Ocean
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Illustration of a boat over a milky sky ocean

fields.Research Focus: Agricultural sustainability and climate change impacts/adaptation; spatial data science and modeling
fields.Spatial Angle: International Partners: Researchers involved with this study include Maria Gisbert-Queral (CSU, University of Copenhagen, Technology Centre of Catalonia), Arne Henningsen and Bo Markussen (University of Copenhagen), Meredith Niles (University of Vermont), Ermias Kebreab (University of California, Davis) and Angela Rigden (Harvard University).

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Research Focus: RELAMPAGO field study: Study of severe convective storms in the lee of the Andes Mountains in central Argentina, which can have devastating impacts in this wine growing region
fields.Primary Story Content:
Cloud Climate interactions

Kristen Rasmussen’s research interests include investigating the global population of convective storms from the TRMM and GPM spaceborne precipitation radars, extreme deep convection in South America, flooding in Pakistan and India, cloud and mesoscale processes, high-impact weather, hydrometeorology, cloud-climate interactions, and convection-permitting regional climate modeling.

fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of a thunderstorm sky

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Spatial Angle: Computer Science
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of illuminated electronic hardware

fields.Primary Story Content: CSU Professor Robin Reid works with people in Kenya, Mongolia, and Colorado, applying science to help them address issues that matter most to their communities. A professor in the Department of Ecosystem Science and Sustainability, Reid heads CSU's Center for Collaborative Conservation. She spent 20 years in East Africa, where she developed a process of continuous engagement among landowners, communities, nongovernmental organizations, government, and scientists to address issues ranging from elephant poaching in Africa to wildfire mitigation in the American West.
fields.Spatial Angle: Wildfire prevalence in the US. Areas where elephant poaching is the most severe.

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Research Focus: chemical pathways for diseases -- research in Thailand on malaria, HIV, etc.
fields.Primary Story Content: It is not enough to develop a drug to combat disease; scientists must also discover the proper dose. While some of this testing is done on animals, Dr. Brad Reisfeld, professor in the CSU Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, saw a different way — a mathematical approach, modeling biological systems and chemical pathways to better understand the effects of drugs on humans and animals. Dr. Reisfeld's research has been used to optimize dosing for pulmonary tuberculosis, as well as several diseases important in Thailand such as malaria, HIV, and Steven-Johnson Syndrome.

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content: The human gut contains tens of trillions of microorganisms, and these bacteria interact intimately with the immune system. The food that we eat impacts which bacteria are present and can ultimately reduce the risk of developing cancer and infectious disease. Dr. Elizabeth Ryan studies one of the world’s most abundant foods — rice — and its potential role in both modulating gut health to reduce disease, and increasing food security in lower- and middle-income countries. Ryan works in many countries but is starting a new project with the International Rice Research Institute in the Philippines, characterizing the way rice byproducts like rice bran can be used to improve global health and food security.
fields.Spatial Angle: Map of major rice crops in the US

fields.Research Focus: Climate Change, Food Security, Human-Elephant Conflict - Uganda
fields.Primary Story Content: Jonathan Salerno, new to CSU, is an ecologist in the Department of Human Dimensions of Natural Resources studying how and why humans make decisions, particularly in response to environmental changes. Salerno’s work tries to better understand human behavior in the context of biodiversity conservation and natural resource management. One of his current research projects focuses on human-elephant interactions, mostly through crop depredation, in southern Africa, and people adapt to negative impacts to support food security.
fields.Spatial Angle:
How the heck can we map human-elephant interactions and food security?? Let's do it.

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Research Focus: CSU- Animal Population Animal Health Institute (APHI) is a reference center for FAO in animal disease surveillance and epidemiology.
fields.Primary Story Content:
infectious diseases

Dr. Salman has created an enduring legacy through landmark changes in global veterinary preventive medicine, including emerging animal diseases, epidemiology and food safety.
Many of his activities stabilize and rebuild national animal health programs in countries such as Bosnia, Afghanistan, Iraq, Middle East, East Africa, Georgia and Armenia. Last year, Dr. Salman facilitated the International Memorandum of Understanding between the China Animal Health and Epidemiology Center (CAHEC) and CSU, which opened doors to technical collaborations.
https://www.avma.org/news/press-releases/dr-mo-salman-honored-2020-avma-public-service-award

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Research Focus: RELAMPAGO field study: Study of severe convective storms in the lee of the Andes Mountains in central Argentina, which can have devastating impacts in this wine growing region
fields.Primary Story Content: What conditions are most conducive to extreme local rainfall? What processes determine whether a storm will produce a large amount of rain in a small area vs. a small amount spread among a large area? How can we improve our forecasting of heavy rain events? Knowing where it is going to rain, for how long, and how hard is the key to understanding everything from agriculture to flooding. And these questions are at the forefront of Dr. Russ Schumacher's work as the Colorado State Climatologist and leader of the CSU-based Colorado Climate Center.
fields.Spatial Angle:
Mesoscale meteorology - severe weather?

Colorado Climate Center
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of a pink umbrella in a rainstorm

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Primary Story Content: Without water, there is no life — and every drop counts. Sybil Sharvelle, Ph.D., associate professor of civil and environmental engineering at CSU, is researching water conservation systems such as graywater and stormwater reuse in urban and arid environments. In 2018, Sharvelle and her team secured a $3 million NSF grant to develop a national traineeship program to train the next generation of scientific leaders “to tackle complex societal programs.” The program — InTERFEWS (Interdisciplinary Training, Education and Research in Food-Energy-Water Systems in Semi-Arid Regions) — taps the skills and interests of Ph.D. students from disparate disciplines to research innovations that foster a more sustainable, waste-free future for all.

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Research Focus: International supply chains and illicit trade
fields.Primary Story Content: Underground networks traffic in everything from illegal weapons and drugs to looted antiquities to exotic animal products or even human beings. These networks are often highly technologically sophisticated and operate with impunity across borders, funneling profits to criminal and terrorist organizations, undermining governments, and victimizing marginalized people. CSU engineering professor Steve Simske wants to help put an end to all that. Between 2008-2012, Dr. Simske pioneering a counterfeit image-detection technology at HP. Through added customization and analytic capabilities, Simske hopes this technology can monitor various supply chains and scan for statistically relevant deviations in order to differentiate legitimate and illicit supply chains.
fields.Spatial Angle: Illicit Trade Map
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of multi-colored Post-It notes on a wall

fields.Research Focus: Dr. Jennifer Solomon’s research focuses on the interface of development, livelihoods and collaborative resource management in communities adjacent to protected areas. She has evaluated integrated conservation and development projects in Latin America and East Africa. She also develops and tests innovative social science research methods for assessing non-compliance with resource regulations. In the past years she has started new research efforts focused on the human dimensions of the lionfish invasion as well as women in conservation leadership.
fields.Spatial Angle: Lionfish observations (potentially- depending on the content of the research highlighted in the story map) Belize
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Image of a lionfish in dark water

fields.Research Focus: Human - wildlife conflict in India Dr. Teel's work focuses on improving conservation decision-making through understanding human thought and behavior and through building social science capacity among conservation professionals. Much of her research has been devoted to examining human-wildlife relationships in the U.S. and globally, with a particular focus on employing concepts and methodologies from social psychology to study human values toward wildlife, attitudes toward wildlife-related issues, and the social factors underlying human-wildlife conflict.

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content: All cats — domestic and wild — can become infected with feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV), resulting in a disease process comparable to HIV in humans. CSU veterinarian Dr. Sue VandeWoude’s laboratory studies factors that contribute to FIV transmission and the development and progression of the disease in cats. The ultimate goal of this research is to translate these findings to better understand viruses in humans. Dr. VandeWoude is currently on a Fulbright sabbatical studying wildlife disease ecology in Tasmania.

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Primary Story Content: V. "Chandra" Chandrasekaran, professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at CSU, is one of the world's leading experts in geoscience and remote sensing — a field that uses data from satellites to advance understanding of the land, oceans, atmosphere, and space. His work with meteorological radar systems has led to technologies that protect lives and improve weather forecasting all over the world — including Finland, where he was knighted by the government for his international work.
fields.Spatial Angle: Locations with severe hurricanes and tornados: If this exists, let's not recreate it.

fields.Primary Story Content: In Antarctica, the frozen ground looks barren – but dig into it, and put it under a microscope, and you’ll see tiny rugged worms, nematodes, that could help unlock our understanding of Earth’s changing climate. CSU professor Diana Wall has been making the voyage to the bottom of the globe every year since 1989 — more than 30 years of studying the life hidden in the Antarctic soil. Exploring the soil, studying the diversity of microbes and invertebrates, can shed light on how human activities around the world affect the health, productivity, and fertility of soils worldwide.

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
Unit/Program: Energy Institute; Engines & Energy Conversion Laboratory
fields.Primary Story Content: Electric power is scarce in Rwanda, where 1-in-4 people has an electric hookup, a hookup rate that drops to 1-in-10 in rural areas. CSU professor Bryan Willson’s work harnessing the University’s energy expertise to bring clean, affordable energy to Rwanda is just one example of Willson’s 25 years of work in more than 40 countries. The teams in Willson’s research lab, the Engines and Energy Conversion Lab are innovators in world needs like energy production and engine technology, advanced electrical grids, and biofuels. In Rwanda, AC/DC microgrids are powering people’s daily lives and boosting the entire country’s economic wellbeing.

An estimated 100,000 elephants were killed in Africa for the ivory in their tusks and teeth from 2010 to 2012 alone. Elephants are among the slowest-producing mammals in the world; and it could take almost a century for forest elephants to recover from these intense levels of poaching. Despite this pressure, the structure of their social networks has remained remarkably stable. World-renowned elephant expert and CSU associate professor George Wittemeyer has spent his career of more than 20 years tracking elephants. He has tracked more than 1,000 individuals and 70 families to date — studying not only the effects of poaching on elephant populations and their social bonds, but the effects of habitat destruction from railroad, highway, and oil pipeline construction, and the resiliency of elephant communities.
